This is the second edition of our book (The Pilgrimage of the Prophet, peace be upon him, as Narrated by Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him). First: Many pilgrims, when they enter Ihram for Hajj, do not feel at all that they have entered into an act of worship that obligates them to stay away from what Allah Almighty has forbidden for them specifically and for every Muslim generally. Likewise, you see them perform Hajj and finish it without any change in their deviant behavior from before Hajj. That is practical proof from them that their Hajj is not complete, if not to say: not accepted. Therefore, every pilgrim must remember this and strive to the best of his ability not to fall into what Allah has forbidden him of immorality and sins. For Allah, Blessed and Exalted, says: (Hajj is [during] well-known months, so whoever has made Hajj obligatory upon himself therein [by entering the state of Ihram], there is [to be for him] no sexual relations and no disobedience and no disputing during Hajj) - Al-Baqarah: 197. And the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: (Authentic) (Whoever performs Hajj and does not have sexual relations nor commits sin, returns from his sins as the day his mother bore him) extracted by the Two Sheikhs. 'Rafath' is sexual intercourse. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said: (And there is nothing among the prohibitions that invalidates Hajj except the genus of sexual intercourse (Rafath), that is why He distinguished between it and Fusuq (disobedience). As for other prohibitions like clothing and perfume, even if one sins by them, they do not invalidate Hajj according to any of the famous Imams). He refers at the end of his speech to the fact that there are scholars who say [4]

that Hajj is invalidated by any sin the pilgrim commits. Among these is Imam Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, for he says: (And whoever intentionally commits a sin, whatever sin it may be, while remembering his Hajj, from the time he completes his Tawaf of the House for Ifadah and stones the Jamrah, his Hajj is invalidated...) and he used the previous verse as evidence. So refer to his book (Al-Muhalla) (7 / 186) for it is important. From the foregoing, it becomes clear that sin from the pilgrim either invalidates his Hajj according to Ibn Hazm's opinion, or he incurs sin by it. But this sin is not like if it issued from a non-pilgrim; rather, it is much more dangerous. For among its effects is that he does not return from his sins as his mother bore him, as stated in the previous hadith. Thus, it is as if he lost his Hajj because he did not obtain the fruit from it, which is the forgiveness of Allah Almighty. So Allah's help is sought. If this is clear, I must warn against some sins which people are frequently afflicted with, and they enter Ihram for Hajj without feeling at all that they must give them up. That is due to their ignorance, the prevalence of heedlessness over them, and their imitation of their fathers.

We have seen many pilgrims falling into Shirk while they are in the Sacred House of Allah and in the Mosque of the Prophet, peace be upon him. They leave supplicating to Allah and seeking His aid for seeking help from prophets and righteous people, swearing by them, and invoking them besides Allah Almighty. And Allah Almighty says: (If you invoke them, they do not hear your supplication; and if they heard, they would not respond to you. And on the Day of Resurrection they will deny your association. And none can inform you like [one] Acquainted [with all matters]) - Fatir: 14. The verses with this meaning are very many, and this is sufficient for one who opens his heart to guidance. Since the purpose now is not deep research into this issue but only reminding. I wonder what these people benefit from their Hajj to the Sacred House of Allah if they insist on such Shirk and change its name, calling it: Tawassul (seeking means), Tashaffu' (seeking intercession), and Wasitah (intermediary). Is this not the intermediary that the polytheists of old claimed to justify their Shirk and worship of others besides Him, Blessed and Exalted: (And those who take protectors besides Him [say], "We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah in position") - Az-Zumar: 3 [6]

So O pilgrim, before you resolve to perform Hajj, it is an individual obligation upon you to hasten to know pure Monotheism (Tawhid) and what contradicts it of Shirk, by studying the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace be upon him. For whoever holds fast to them is saved, and whoever deviates from them is led astray. And Allah's help is sought.

Upon discussing this with them, it became clear that they are of three types: Some of them do not know its prohibition, so they would hasten to remove it after we mention to them some of the prohibiting texts like the hadith: (Authentic) (He, peace be upon him, forbade the gold ring) Agreed upon. that by doing so he combines two sins: Opposing his explicit prohibition, peace be upon him, as preceded, and imitating the disbelievers, because the engagement ring was not known among Muslims until before this era, then this custom spread to them from the traditions of the Christians. I have detailed the discussion on this issue in (Adab al-Zifaf) as well (p. 131 - 138) and clarified in it that the mentioned prohibition includes women as well, contrary to the majority, so refer to (p. 139 - 167) for it is very important. Second: We advise everyone who wants to perform Hajj to study the rituals of Hajj in the light of the Book and the Sunnah before embarking on the Hajj actions so that it may be complete and accepted by Allah Blessed and Exalted. I only said: based on the Book and the Sunnah, because disagreement has occurred in the rituals - regrettably - just as it occurred in other acts of worship. For example: Is it better to intend Tamattu', Qiran, or Ifrad in his Hajj? There are three schools of thought. What we see regarding that is only Tamattu', which is the Madhhab of Imam Ahmad and others. Rather, some verifying scholars went so far as to say it is obligatory if he does not drive the sacrificial animal (Hady) with him, among them Ibn Hazm [10]

and Ibn al-Qayyim, following Ibn Abbas and others from the Salaf. You find the detailed discussion on that in the book (Al-Muhalla) and (Zad al-Ma'ad) and others. I do not wish now to delve into this issue in detail, but rather I want to mention a brief word that will benefit, God willing, whoever is sincere and whose goal is following the truth, not imitating fathers or the Madhhab. So I say: There is no doubt that Hajj, at the beginning of his resumption of it, peace be upon him, was permissible in its three aforementioned types. Likewise, his companions, peace be upon him, some were Mutamatte', some were Qarin, and some were Mufrid, because he, peace be upon him, gave them the choice in that as in the hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: (Authentic) (We went out with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and he said: Whoever among you wants to assume Ihram for Hajj and Umrah, let him do so. And whoever wants to assume Ihram for Hajj, let him assume Ihram. And whoever wants to assume Ihram for Umrah, let him assume Ihram...) The hadith narrated by Muslim. This choice was at the beginning of their Ihram at the Tree (1) as in a narration by Ahmad (6 / 245). Aisha said in a narration from her: (Sahih) (...So we camped at Sarif, and the Prophet (peace be upon him) said to his companions: 'Whoever does not have a sacrificial animal (Hady) with him and wishes to make it an Umrah, let him do so, and whoever has a sacrificial animal with him, let him not.' She said: So among his companions, there were those who took it and those who left it [from those who did not have Hady]...) The Hadith is agreed upon, and the addition is from Muslim. And among that is when he (peace be upon him) reached (Dhu Tuwa), a place near Mecca, and spent the night there. When he prayed Fajr, he said to them: (Sahih) ('Whoever wishes to make it an Umrah, let him make it an Umrah'). Recorded by the two Sheikhs from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas. However, we saw him (peace be upon him) when he entered Mecca and performed the Arrival Tawaf (Tawaf al-Qudum) along with his companions, he did not leave them on the previous ruling which was merely preference; rather, he moved them to a new ruling which is obligation. He commanded those among them who did not drive the Hady to annul the Hajj into an Umrah and exit Ihram. Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said: (Sahih) ('We went out with the Prophet (peace be upon him) not considering it anything but Hajj. When we arrived in Mecca, we circumambulated the House, and the Prophet (peace be upon him) commanded those who had not driven the Hady to exit Ihram. She said: So those who had not driven the Hady exited Ihram, and his wives had not [11]

text: driven [the Hady], so they exited Ihram...') The Hadith is agreed upon. And from Ibn Abbas similar to it with the wording: (Sahih) ('So he commanded them to make it an Umrah. That seemed momentous to them, so they said: "O Messenger of Allah, what kind of Hal (exiting Ihram)?" He said: "The complete Hal."') Agreed upon. And in the Hadith of Jabir is similar to it and clearer than it, as will come in paragraph (33-45). I say: Whoever contemplates these authentic Hadiths, it will become clear to him with a clarity unmixed with doubt that the choice mentioned in them was only from him (peace be upon him) to prepare the souls and ready them to accept a new ruling that might be difficult for some to accept easily at first glance. That is the command to annul the Hajj into an Umrah, especially since they used to in the Days of Ignorance - as is established in the (Two Sahihs) - consider that Umrah is not permissible in the months of Hajj. And this opinion, even if the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) had invalidated it by him (peace be upon him) performing Umrah three times in three years, all of them in the month of Dhu al-Qi'dah, this alone, even if it was sufficient to invalidate that Jahiliyyah innovation, implies - and there is no contextual indicator here, rather it is not sufficient - Allah knows best - to prepare the souls to accept the new ruling. Therefore, he (peace be upon him) paved the way for it by giving them the choice between Hajj and Umrah while explaining what is best for them, then he followed that with the decisive command to annul the Hajj into an Umrah as preceded [12]

text: So if we know that, then this command is definitively for obligation. The following matters indicate this: First: The default in it is obligation unless there is a contextual indicator [to the contrary], and there is no contextual indicator here. Rather, the contextual indicator here confirms it, which is the following matter: Second: That when he (peace be upon him) commanded them, it seemed momentous to them as preceded just now. If it were not for obligation, they would not have found it momentous. Do you not see that he (peace be upon him) had commanded them before three times with a command of choice, yet they did not find it momentous? This indicates that they understood obligation from the command, and that is what is intended. Third: That in a narration in the Hadith of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her), she said: (Sahih) (...He entered upon me while he was angry. I said: "Who has angered you, O Messenger of Allah? May Allah admit him to the Fire." He said: "Have you not felt that I commanded the people with a command, and behold, they are hesitating? Al-Hakam said: As if they are hesitating. I think [he said]: 'And if I had faced my affair as I have turned my back on it, I would not have driven the Hady with me until I bought it, then I would have exited Ihram as they exited.'") Narrated by Muslim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad (6 / 175). So in his anger (peace be upon him) is clear evidence that his command was for obligation, especially since his anger (peace be upon him) was only because of their hesitation, not because of their refusal to execute the command - far be it from them to do that. Therefore, they all exited Ihram except for those who had Hady with them, as will come in paragraph (44) [13]

text: Fourth: His saying (peace be upon him) when they asked him about the annulment which he commanded them: ('Is it for this year of ours or for forever and ever?') So he (peace be upon him) interlaced his fingers one into another and said: ('Umrah has entered into Hajj until the Day of Resurrection. No, rather for forever and ever. No, rather for forever and ever.') As will come in paragraph (24). This is a clear text that Umrah has become an indivisible part of Hajj and that this ruling is not specific to the Companions as some think, rather it continues forever. (1) Fifth: If the command were not for obligation, it would have sufficed for some of the Companions to execute it. So how [can that be] when we have seen the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) not satisfying himself with commanding the people to annul generally? For sometimes he commands his daughter Fatimah (may Allah be pleased with her) with that, as will come (paragraph 48), and sometimes he commands his wives with it, as in the (Two Sahihs) from Ibn Umar that the Prophet (peace be upon him) commanded his wives to exit Ihram in the year of the Farewell Hajj. Hafsah said: So I said: "What prevents you from exiting Ihram?" He said: ('I have matted my hair...') The Hadith. And when Abu Musa came from Yemen as a pilgrim, he (peace be upon him) said to him: ('With what have you assumed Ihram?') He said: "I assumed Ihram with the Ihram of the Prophet (peace be upon him)." He said: "Have you driven the Hady?" He said: "No." He said: ('Then circulate around the House and between Safa and Marwah, then exit Ihram...') The Hadith.

text: Does this intense eagerness from the Prophet (peace be upon him) to convey his command of annulment to every responsible person not indicate obligation? By Allah, indeed obligation is established by less than this. Due to the clarity of these evidences indicating the obligation of annulment - let alone Tamattu' - the opposers had no choice but to submit to their indication. Then they differed in answering them. Some claimed it was specific to the Companions, and you have known the falsehood of that from what preceded. And some claimed it was abrogated, but they were unable to mention even a single evidence worth mentioning and refuting, except for the prohibition of Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) and likewise Uthman and Ibn Al-Zubayr, as in the (Two Sahihs) and others. The answer is from several aspects: First: That those who use this prohibition as proof against Mut'ah (Tamattu') do not hold that view, because their school of thought allows it. So whatever their answer is to it, is our answer. Second: That this prohibition was opposed by a group of the Companions of the Prophet (peace be upon him), among them Ali, Imran bin Husain, Ibn Abbas, and others. Third: That it is an opinion contrary to the Book, let alone the Sunnah. Allah said: [15]

text: The Exalted said: (Then whoever performs 'Umrah [during the Hajj months] followed by Hajj [offers] what can be obtained with ease of sacrificial animals) Al-Baqarah: 196. Imran bin Husain (may Allah be pleased with him) pointed to this meaning by his saying: (Sahih) ('We performed Tamattu' with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and the Quran was not revealed regarding it [forbidding it] (and in a narration: The verse of Mut'ah was revealed in the Book of Allah - meaning Mut'ah of Hajj - and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) commanded us with it until he died). A man said with his opinion after that what he wished.') Narrated by Muslim. Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) explicitly stated the legitimacy of Tamattu' and that his prohibition of it or his dislike for it was only an opinion he held for a reason that appeared to him. He said: (Sahih) ('I knew that the Prophet (peace be upon him) and his companions did it, but I disliked that they would remain *mu'arrisiin* with them (1) in the Arak (2) then go for Hajj while their heads were dripping') Narrated by Muslim and Ahmad. text: Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) relied upon for his dislike of Tamattu' is the very same one that the Companions, who did not hasten to execute his command (peace be upon him) to annul, used as an excuse for leaving the immediate action. They said: ('We went out as pilgrims not desiring anything but Hajj. Until there was only four nights between us and Arafat, he commanded us to go in unto our women, so we would come to Arafat with our male organs dripping with semen from the women...') See paragraph (40). The Prophet (peace be upon him) rejected that by his saying: ('Is it by Allah that you teach me, O people? You have known that I am the most God-fearing of you to Allah, the most truthful of you, and the most righteous of you. Do what I command you, for were it not for my Hady, I would have exited Ihram as you exit.') (Paragraph 42). This clarifies to us that if Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) had recalled, when he disliked Tamattu' for the people, this statement of the Companions which is like his statement, and remembered with it the rebuttal of the Prophet (peace be upon him) to them, he would not have disliked that nor forbidden the people from it. In this is evidence that a Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) or a saying of his sayings may be hidden from a noble Companion, so he performs Ijtihad with his opinion and errs, and he is despite that rewarded, not burdened with sin. Infallibility belongs to Allah alone, then to His Messenger. A sayer might say: "What you mentioned of evidences for the obligation of Tamattu' and for rejecting what contradicts it is clear and acceptable, but it is problematic due to what some mention [17]

text: that the Rightly Guided Caliphs all performed Ifrad for Hajj, so how is the reconciliation between this and what you mentioned? The answer: It has previously been explained that Tamattu' is only obligatory upon the one who did not drive the Hady. As for the one who drove the Hady, that is not obligatory upon him; rather, it is not permissible for him. Instead, he must perform Qiran, which is best, or perform Ifrad. So it is probable that what was reported about the Caliphs regarding Ifrad is only because they had driven the Hady. In that case, there is no contradiction, and all praise is due to Allah. The summary of the speech: Every person who intends Hajj must perform his Ihram for Umrah, then exit from it after finishing the Sa'i between Safa and Marwah by shortening his hair. On the eighth day of Dhu al-Hijjah, he assumes Ihram for Hajj. So whoever had stated Talbiyah for Qiran or Ifrad must annul that into Umrah in obedience to his Prophet (peace be upon him). And Allah Almighty says: (He who obeys the Messenger has obeyed Allah) - An-Nisa: 80. After that, the Mutamatti' (one performing Tamattu') must offer a Hady on the Day of Sacrifice or during the Days of Tashreeq. It is from the completeness of the ritual, and it is a blood of gratitude, not a blood of reparation. It is - as Ibn al-Qayyim said - in the status of the Udhiyah (sacrifice) for the resident, and it is from the completeness of the worship of this day. So the ritual that includes blood is like the Eid that includes the Udhiyah, and it is among the best of deeds. Know that this paragraph from the hadith of Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, has been challenged in its authenticity by some scholars in terms of its chain and text. As for the chain, because he did not assertively raise it to the Prophet, peace be upon him, due to the narrator's saying: "I think" and in a narration by Muslim "I see", which means doubt and lack of certainty. As for the text, Iraq had not been conquered at that time. The answer to the first is from two perspectives: A - That the doubt has been removed by the narrator's assertion of raising the hadith to the Prophet, peace be upon him, in the narration of Ibn Majah referred to above, which, although weak as previously mentioned, the assertion has been established in another narration extracted by Imam Ahmad. Although it contains Ibn Lahi'ah who is described with poor memory, among his narrators from him is Abdullah bin Wahb with Imam Al-Bayhaqi (5 / 27). Such a narration is authentic according to the verifying Imams because the narration of the Abadillah from Ibn Lahi'ah is authentic according to them, and they are Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak, Abdullah bin Yazid Al-Muqri, and Abdullah bin Wahb. This has been elaborated by the scholar Ibn Al-Qayyim in "I'lam Al-Muwaqqi'in" (3 / 13 - 14), so let whoever wants elaboration refer to it. B - Suppose the doubt was not removed by that, the hadith has many witnesses from a group of Companions strengthening Jabir's hadith as asserted by Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar and others. He cited the referred witnesses in "Al-Talkhis". Al-Zayla'i also cited them in "Nasb Al-Rayah" (2 / 12 - 15) and Ibn Kathir as in "Al-Jawhar Al-Naqi" (5 / 28). This comment cannot bear mentioning those witnesses, so let whoever wishes refer to them in some of the mentioned sources. But it is necessary here to mention one witness that escaped all those extractors, which is what Al-Tahawi extracted (1 / 360) and Abu Nu'aym in "Al-Hilyah" (4 / 94) with an authentic chain from Ibn Umar that he said following his hadith referred to regarding the Meeqats: "And our companions told me that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, set Dhat Irq for the people of Iraq." Abu Nu'aym said: This is an authentic established hadith. I say: In this is a refutation of those who weakened the hadith absolutely and those who strengthened it by the sum of its paths not by itself. What is in Sahih Al-Bukhari that Umar bin Al-Khattab is the one who set Dhat Irq for the people of Iraq does not contradict the authenticity of the hadith, as it is possible that this was among the agreements where Umar agreed with the legislation. As for the answer to its defect that Iraq had not been conquered at that time, it is: That this issued from him, peace be upon him, and issued as instruction for the nation of Islam until the Day of Judgment. So it is not necessary that it be conquered at that time. It is like the lands of Sham in this regard, for they had not been conquered either as is known. Therefore, Al-Hafiz Ibn Abd al-Barr said: This is negligence from the one who said this saying, because he, peace be upon him, is the one who set Dhat Irq for the people of Iraq just as he set Al-Juhfah for the people of Sham, and Sham at that time was an abode of disbelief like Iraq. So he set the Meeqats for the people of the regions because he knew that Allah would open Sham, Iraq, and others for his Ummah. Sham and Iraq were only conquered during the time of Umar without dispute. And he, peace be upon him, said: Iraq withheld its dirham and its qafiz. The hadith means according to the people of knowledge it will withhold." Ibn Al-Turkmani quoted it in "Al-Jawhar" (5 / 28 - 29) and "and its dirham" occurred in it instead of "and its qafiz", and I corrected it from "Sahih Muslim" (8 / 175)

foot_note:
1. (8) That was after he combed his hair, applied oil, and wore his lower garment (Izar) and upper garment (Rida), he and his companions. He did not forbid any Izars and Ridas to be worn except the Muza'far. As Ibn Abbas said in Al-Bukhari. The Muza'far is what is dyed with yellow color like saffron. So in it, meaning the hadith of Ibn Abbas, is the legislation of wearing Ihram clothes before the Meeqat, contrary to what many people think. This is unlike the intention of Ihram, for it is not permissible according to the most correct opinion in our view except at the Meeqat or close to it for one who is in an airplane and fears that it will pass the Meeqat and he has not entered Ihram. Know that uttering the intention is not legislated neither in Ihram nor in other acts of worship like purification, prayer, fasting, and others. The intention is only in the heart. As for uttering it, it is an innovation "and every innovation is a misguidance and every misguidance is in the Fire". What is authentically reported from him, peace be upon him, in Ihram is only his saying: "Labbayk Allahumma Umrah and Hajj". So one stops at this and does not add to it as decided by Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah in his treatise on "Intention" (p. 244 - 245 of Majmu'at Al-Rasa'il Al-Kubra Part One). He has a statement on this issue mentioned in his "Mansik" (2 / 359) whose apparent meaning might contradict what we mentioned, so it should not be paid attention to. You must know the truth by its evidence not by its speaker, especially if he has two opinions on the issue 
9. Meaning from Dhu al-Hulayfah as in the "Two Sahihs" from the hadith of Ibn Umar. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said in his explanation: It contains the recommendation to drive the sacrificial animal from the Meeqats and from distant places, and it is one of the Sunnahs that many people have neglected. Thus he said, and it is questionable because driving the sacrificial animal is not something his guidance, peace be upon him, settled on. Rather, he regretted it as in the coming paragraph (41): "Had I known beforehand about my affair what I know now, I would not have driven the sacrificial animal and I would have made it lawful." This statement from him, peace be upon him, indicated two important matters: First: That enjoying Umrah until Hajj with releasing from Ihram between them is better than driving the sacrificial animal with Qiran, because he, peace be upon him, regretted not doing that, and it can only be for what is better obviously. So the best is therefore leaving driving the sacrificial animal. Second: That everyone who did not drive the sacrificial animal among the pilgrims, whether he was Qarin or Mufrid, must release from that with an Umrah then assume Ihram for Hajj on the Day of Tarwiyah due to his command, peace be upon him, to do that as will come. Rather, it is authentic that the Prophet, peace be upon him, was angry with those who did not hasten to implement his command to release. He, peace be upon him, confirmed that by saying: "Umrah has entered into Hajj until the Day of Judgment." This is also a text that Umrah has become an integral part of Hajj. So every pilgrim must combine with his Hajj an Umrah, either without releasing from it if he had driven the sacrificial animal with him, or by releasing if he did not drive the sacrificial animal. This was said by Ibn Hazm and he quoted it from Ibn Abbas, Mujahid, Ata, Ishaq bin Rahwayh and others. Ibn Al-Qayyim supported it in "Zad Al-Ma'ad" with great support, so let whoever wants elaboration refer to it 
[48].

15. From Ihlal which is raising the voice with Talbiyah. It is said: The Muhrim raised his voice with Hajj, he raises it (Yuhillu) raising (Ihlalan): if he said Talbiyah and raised his voice. So in Al-Nihaya. In the hadith, it is stated that he, peace be upon him, assumed Ihram for Hajj alone, but in the hadith of Anas and others in the Two Sahihs and others, it is stated that he, peace be upon him, raised his voice with Hajj and Umrah together, and this is the correct view as explained by Ibn Al-Qayyim in "Zad Al-Ma'ad". He cited about twenty hadiths from about twenty Companions that the Prophet, peace be upon him, performed Hajj as Qarin (combining Hajj and Umrah). Let whoever wants to expand on the investigation refer to it. He missed the saying of Aisha: "O Messenger of Allah, do you set out with Hajj and Umrah and I set out with Hajj" which is in Al-Bukhari and Ahmad from the hadith of Jabir himself, and it is a text on the issue. See the coming paragraph (111). Based on this, Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, knew that the Prophet, peace be upon him, was Qarin, so how does he report about him that he raised his voice with Hajj alone and singled it out? The answer is from two perspectives: First: That it is interpreted as the beginning of Ihram. And before his descent, peace be upon him, in Wadi Al-Aqiq where he was commanded with Qiran as Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, reported. He said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, in Wadi Al-Aqiq: An Umrah in (and in a narration: and) a Hajj". Narrated by Al-Bukhari and others. There is remoteness in this in my view because Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, was not alone in narrating Ifrad (singling out) from him, peace be upon him, but a group of Companions followed him in it, like Lady Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, in the Two Sahihs and others. And in a narration by Muslim and "Al-Muwatta" and Ibn Sa'd from her with Jabir's explicit wording: "He singled out Hajj". It is difficult then to hold the mentioned interpretation because it attributes lack of knowledge to the Companions. Therefore, a group of scholars chose the first perspective, like Ibn Al-Mundhir, Ibn Hazm and Qadi Iyad, and Al-Hafiz preferred it in "Al-Fath". So whoever wants to expand on the investigation let him refer to it. As for Ibn Al-Qayyim's defecting of this explicit narration of Jabir by Al-Darawardi being alone in it, it is refuted by the fact that Abdul-Aziz bin Abi Hazim followed him in it. Ibn Sa'd extracted it in "Al-Tabaqat" (2 / 1 / 179) 
[51].

1. (18) This indicates the permissibility of adding to the Prophetic Talbiyah because of his approval, peace be upon him, of them for it. Malik and Al-Shafi'i said this. Ahmad narrated from Ibn Abbas that he said: "Stick to it, for it is the Talbiyah of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him." Some contemporaries authenticated its chain, but it contains one who became confused. It is authentically reported from Abu Hurairah that part of his Talbiyah, peace be upon him, was: Labbayk Ilaha Al-Haqq. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i and others. Talbiyah is answering the call of Allah Almighty to His creation when He called them to Hajj His House on the tongue of His friend (Khalil). 58 - So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) moved (52). Quraysh did not doubt that he would stop at the Sacred Monument (Mash'ar Al-Haram) [at Muzdalifah: D, JA, HQ] [and his stopping place would be there: M] as Quraysh used to do in the Jahiliyyah (53). But the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed (54) until he came to Arafah and found the dome had been pitched for him at Namirah, so he dismounted there.

59 - Until the sun passed the meridian, he ordered Al-Qaswa (his camel), so it was saddled for him. He [rode until: D, MJ] he came to the bottom of the valley (55). Sermon of Arafat
foot_note:
1. (51) With Fatha on the Nun and Kasra on the Mim. Ibn al-Athir said: "It is the mountain on which the markers of the Haram are at Arafat." Namirah is not part of Arafat.
52. His companions in this march: some were reciting Talbiyah and some were saying Takbir, as in the hadith of Anas in the Two Sahihs.
53. The meaning of this is that Quraysh in Jahiliyyah used to stand at the Sacred Monument, which is a mountain in Muzdalifah called Quzah. The rest of the Arabs used to pass Muzdalifah and stand at Arafat. So Quraysh thought the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would stand at the Sacred Monument according to their habit and not pass it. But he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed it to Arafat because Allah the Exalted ordered him to do so in His saying: (Then depart from the place from where [all] the people depart), meaning the rest of the Arabs other than Quraysh. Quraysh only stood at Muzdalifah because it is from the Haram, and they used to say: We are the people of Allah's Haram, so we do not leave it. Nawawi.
54. Al-Nawawi said: This is metaphorical, meaning he approached Arafat because he explained it by saying 'he found the dome pitched at Namirah and dismounted there,' and it preceded that Namirah is not part of Arafat [69].

text: 60 - He addressed the people and said: (Indeed, your blood and your wealth are sacred to you like the sanctity of this day of yours, in this month of yours, in this land of yours. Behold, [and: MJ, JA] [indeed: D, MI, MJ, HQ] everything of the matter of Jahiliyyah is under [these two: MJ, JA] feet of mine, abolished. The blood feuds of Jahiliyyah are abolished, and the first blood I abolish of our blood is the blood of Ibn Rabi'a bin Al-Harith [bin Abdul Muttalib: D, HQ] - he was nursing among Bani Sa'd and Hudhayl killed him. The usury (Riba) of Jahiliyyah is abolished, and the first usury I abolish is our usury: the usury of Abbas bin Abdul Muttalib, for it is abolished entirely (56). So fear Allah regarding women, for you have taken them by the trust [trust: D, SHA, MJ, HQ] of Allah (57) and made their private parts lawful by the word
foot_note:
1. (55) It is the valley of Uranah, with Damma on the Ayn and Fatha on the Ra. It is not part of Arafat. Nawawi.
56. Its meaning is the excess over the capital, as Allah the Exalted said: (And if you repent, you may have your principal - [capital]). The meaning of abolition is rejection and annulment.
57. In it is the urging to observe the rights of women, advise regarding them, and treat them with kindness. Many authentic hadiths have come regarding advising about them, clarifying their rights, and warning against shortcomings in that. Let whoever wishes refer to them in "Al-Targhib wa Al-Tarhib" (3: 71 - 74) by Al-Mundhiri and "Riyad al-Salihin" by Al-Nawawi [70].

book_title: The Hajj of the Prophet ﷺ as Narrated by Jabir رضي الله عنه
text:
…and [verily: D Mi Maj Haq] you have rights over your wives: that they do not allow anyone into your beds (or homes) whom you dislike (59). And if they do so, then strike them *without severity* (60). And they have rights over you: their provision and their clothing, according to what is reasonable. And [indeed: Ja Haq] I have left among you that which, if you hold fast to it, you will never go astray after me: the Book of Allah (61).

And you will be asked (and in a wording: are questioned: D Mi Maj Ja Hayq) about me, so what will you say? They said: We bear witness that you have conveyed [the messages of your Lord: Ja] and fulfilled and advised [your Ummah and discharged what was upon you: Ja]. So he said with his index finger, raising it to the sky and pointing it to the people: O Allah, bear witness, O Allah, bear witness) Combining the Two Prayers and Standing at Arafat

61 - Then [Bilal: Mi Maj Ja Hayq] called Adhan [with one call: Mi]

62 - Then he called Iqamah and prayed Dhuhr, then he called Iqamah and prayed Asr

63 - And he did not pray anything between them
foot_note:
58. There are four interpretations mentioned regarding its meaning in the commentary on Sahih Muslim. The correct one is that it refers to Allah’s saying: “Then marry those that please you of women.”
59. The preferred meaning: that they must not permit into your homes anyone whom you dislike—whether a non-mahram man, a woman, or even one of the wife's mahrams. The prohibition covers all such cases, as explained by An-Nawawi. Refer to his full discussion in his commentary on Sahih Muslim.
60. “A severe beating” means a harsh, painful striking. Its meaning here: strike them in a manner that is *not* harsh nor harmful. I (the author) say: This is part of the authority (qiwāmah) of men over women, as Allah said: “Men are guardians over women by what Allah has given one over the other and by what they spend from their wealth… And those [wives] whose disobedience you fear—advise them, forsake them in bed, and strike them; but if they obey you, seek no means against them. Indeed, Allah is Most High, Great.”
61. I (the author) say: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ spoke the truth: for when the later Muslims—except for a few—did not hold firmly to the Book of Allah and did not adhere to the Sunnah of His Prophet ﷺ, they went astray and were humiliated. This happened when they made the opinions and schools of men the primary reference. Whatever from the Qur’an and Sunnah agreed with them, they accepted; and whatever disagreed, they rejected—until one of them even said: “Every verse or hadith that contradicts the madhhab is considered abrogated.” May Allah have mercy on Mālik, who said: ‘The latter part of this Ummah will not be rectified except by what rectified its earliest part.’ Therefore, Muslims must hold fast to the Book of their Lord and make it the judge in all their affairs, and they must not place over it the opinions of men—whether Eastern or Western.
[71].

64 - Then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, rode [Al-Qaswa: Ja] until he came to the standing place (Al-Mawqif), so he made the belly of his she-camel Al-Qaswa face the rocks (62) and put the gathering of pedestrians (63) in front of him and faced the Qibla (64)

65 - So he continued standing until the sun set and the yellow color went a little until the disk disappeared (65)

66 - [And he said: I stood here and all of Arafah is a standing place: D N Mi Maj Ja Ha Ham]
foot_note:
1. (62) They are rocks spread out at the bottom of the Mount of Mercy (Jabal al-Rahmah), which is the mountain in the middle of the land of Arafat. Al-Nawawi said: This is the recommended standing place. As for what is famous among the ignorant commoners of climbing the mountain and their illusion that standing is only valid on it, it is a mistake 
63. Meaning their assembly 
64. It came in more than one hadith that he, peace be upon him, stood supplicating raising his hands. Also from the Sunnah is Talbiyah in his standing at Arafah contrary to what Sheikh Al-Islam mentioned in his Mansik (p. 383). Sa'id bin Jubayr said: We were with Ibn Abbas at Arafah. He said to me: O Sa'id, why do I not hear the people saying Talbiyah? I said: They fear Mu'awiyah. He said: So Ibn Abbas went out of his tent and said: Labbayk Allahumma Labbayk. For they have abandoned the Sunnah out of hatred for Ali, may Allah be pleased with him. Extracted by Al-Hakim (1 / 464 - 465) and Al-Bayhaqi (5 / 113) from the path of Maysarah bin Habib from Al-Minhal bin Amr from him. Al-Hakim said: "Authentic on the condition of the Two Sheikhs" and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. Then Al-Tabarani narrated in "Al-Awsat" (1 / 115 / 2) and Al-Hakim from another path from Ibn Abbas that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, stood at Arafat, and when he said: Labbayk Allahumma Labbayk, he said: Indeed, good is the good of the Hereafter. Its chain is Hasan and Al-Hakim authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. And in the chapter from Maymunah, the wife of the Prophet, peace be upon him, from her action. Extracted by Al-Bayhaqi 
[72].

text: 80 - When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, departed, women in litters (77) passed by him running. So Al-Fadl began looking at them, so the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, put his hand on Al-Fadl's face. So Al-Fadl turned his face to the other side, so the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, turned his hand from the other side on Al-Fadl's face turning his face away from the other side looking (78)
foot_note:
1. (75) And he continued, peace be upon him, with his Talbiyah, not stopping it 
76. In it and in the previous paragraph (Number: 65) is the permissibility of letting someone ride behind if the mount is capable, and the hadiths have supported it as Al-Nawawi said 
77. I say: This story is different from the one narrated by Ali and Ibn Abbas regarding Al-Fadl looking at the Khath'amiyyah woman in several aspects, including: That in their hadith it was on the Day of Nahr, and this was on the morning of Muzdalifah before coming to the valley of Muhassir. And in Ali's hadith is another benefit which is the declaration that the story occurred in Mina at the place of slaughter after throwing Jamrat Al-Aqaba. As narrated by Ahmad (1 / 75 - 76) and his son in his "Zawa'id" (1 / 76 and 81) and Al-Mukhallis in "Al-Fawa'id Al-Muntaqah" (9 / 220 / 1) with a Hasan chain as Al-Hafiz said and Al-Tirmidhi authenticated. In that is a clear refutation of those among the early and late scholars who claim that the Khath'amiyyah woman was in Ihram and that is why the Prophet, peace be upon him, did not order her to cover her face. They say that to reject the explicit indication of the hadith that the woman's face is not 'awrah, for if it were 'awrah he would have ordered her to cover. Even if it were accepted that she was in Ihram, Ihram does not prevent covering, especially in this case where Satan almost entered between her and Al-Fadl. It only prevents Niqab and Burqa' and the like. So how when there is nothing in the hadith that she was in Ihram? And how when it contains that the story was after throwing the Jamrah and at the place of slaughter as preceded, and in this state everything becomes lawful for her except marriage as will come. So if it were assumed that covering was not permissible for her before that, the prohibition has been removed. I have detailed the discussion on that in "Hijab Al-Mar'ah Al-Muslimah", especially in the second edition which is imminent, Allah Almighty willing 
[76].

Throwing the Great Jamrah

72 - Then he took the middle road (81) which comes out [at: N D Mi Maj Ja Hayq] the Great Jamrah until he came to the Jamrah which is at the tree

text: 74 - saying Takbir (Allahu Akbar) with every pebble of them, like the pebbles of Khadhf (flicking) (83)
foot_note:
1. (81) Al-Nawawi said: It implies that taking this road on return from Arafat is a Sunnah, and it is different from the road he took to go to Arafat 
82. And then he stopped, meaning his Talbiyah, as in the hadith of Al-Fadl and others 
83. Al-Nawawi said: "It is about the size of a broad bean. It should not be bigger nor smaller, but if it is bigger or smaller, it suffices." In "Al-Nihaya": "Al-Khadhf is your throwing a pebble or datestone which you hold between your two index fingers and throw." I say: This manner has been mentioned in some hadiths from more than one Companion, including Abdul-Rahman bin Mu'adh Al-Tamimi who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, addressed us while we were at Mina. He said: So our hearing was opened until we could hear what he was saying while we were in our dwellings. He said: So he began teaching us our rituals until he reached the Jamarat, so he said: With pebbles of Khadhf, and he placed his two index fingers one on the other. The Hadith was extracted by Abu Dawud, Al-Nasa'i, Ahmad, and Al-Bayhaqi, and the context is his, with an authentic chain. And in the chapter from Harmala bin Amr in "Amali Al-Mahamili" (5 / 120 / 1) and "Fawa'id Al-Mukhallis" (7 / 184 / 2) and Ibn Abbas in "Tabaqat Ibn Sa'd" in "Al-Tabaqat" (2 / 129) and it is with Muslim in a narration of his (4 / 71). But is the intent of this manner clarification and extra explanation of the pebbles of Khadhf which should be thrown, or is the intent teaching and adhering to it without other manners? Both matters are possible, but the first is more apparent, such that Al-Nawawi did not mention other than it. As for Ibn Al-Humam, he mentioned in "Al-Fath" the second possibility and rejected it, asserting that the intent is the first. Based on this, there is no specific manner for throwing in the Sunnah that should be adhered to. So however throwing is easy for him [he does it]. Here are some alerts: First: It is not permissible to throw on the Day of Nahr (Sacrifice) before sunrise, even for the weak and women who are permitted to depart from Muzdalifah after midnight. They must wait until the sun rises then throw, due to the hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, sent his family ahead and ordered them not to throw at Jamrat Al-Aqaba until the sun rises". It is an authentic hadith by the sum of its paths. Al-Tirmidhi and Ibn Hibban authenticated it, and Al-Hafiz graded it Hasan in "Al-Fath" (3 / 422). It is not valid to oppose it with what is in Al-Bukhari that Asma bint Abi Bakr threw the Jamrah then prayed Fajr after the death of the Prophet, peace be upon him, because it is not explicit that she did that with permission from him, peace be upon him, unlike her departure after midnight, for she explicitly stated that the Prophet, peace be upon him, permitted that for the weak (Za'n). So it is possible that she understood from this permission permission also to throw at night, and his prohibition, peace be upon him, which Ibn Abbas preserved, did not reach her. Second: There is a concession to throw on this day after the sun passes the meridian (Zawal) even until night. So whoever finds hardship in throwing in the forenoon can enjoy it. The evidence is the hadith of Ibn Abbas also who said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, was being asked on the Day of Nahr at Mina and he would say: No harm (La haraj). A man asked him and said: I shaved before I slaughtered? He said: Slaughter and no harm. He said: I threw after evening came. He said: No harm. Narrated by Al-Bukhari and others. Ash-Shawkani went to this view, and before him Ibn Hazm. He said in "Al-Muhalla": The Prophet, peace be upon him, only forbade throwing it before the sun rises on the Day of Nahr, and permitted throwing it after that even if evening comes, and this applies to both night and evening. So preserve this concession, for it saves you from falling into committing the prohibition of the Messenger, peace be upon him, mentioned regarding throwing before sunrise, which many pilgrims violate claiming necessity. Third: That the Muhrim, if he throws Jamrat Al-Aqaba, everything becomes lawful for him except women, even if he has not shaved, due to the hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: "I perfumed the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, with my hand with Dharirah for the Farewell Hajj for the lawful state (Hill) and Ihram when he assumed Ihram and when he threw Jamrat Al-Aqaba on the Day of Nahr before he circumambulated the House". Narrated by Ahmad with an authentic chain on the condition of the Two Sheikhs, and its origin is with them. This was said by Ata, Malik, Abu Thawr, and Abu Yusuf, and it is a narration from Ahmad. Ibn Qudamah said in "Al-Mughni" (3 / 439): "And it is the correct view if Allah Almighty wills." Ibn Hazm went to this view, rather he said: It becomes lawful for him just by the entry of the time of throwing even if he did not throw. As for the condition of shaving with throwing as came in some Madhhabs and more than one writer on rituals, it contradicts this authentic hadith and there is no hadith suitable to oppose it. As for the hadith "If you throw and shave - added in a narration: and slaughter - then everything becomes lawful for you except women", it is weak in chain and disturbed (Mudtarib) in text as I explained in "Al-Ahadith Al-Da'ifah" (Number after one thousand). Fourth: That it is permissible for him to pick up pebbles from wherever he wishes as Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, said. That is because the Prophet, peace be upon him, did not specify a place for that. The most that came regarding it is the hadith of Ibn Abbas (and in a narration: Al-Fadl bin Abbas) who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to me on the morning of Al-Aqaba (and in a narration: the morning of Nahr, and in another: the morning of Jam') while he was on his mount: Pick up for me. So I picked up pebbles for him about the size of pebbles of Khadhf. When I put them in his hand he said: Like these three times, and beware of extremism (Ghulu) in religion, for those before you were destroyed by extremism in religion. Extracted by Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Ibn Al-Jarud in "Al-Muntaqa" (Number 473) and the context is his, Ibn Hibban in his Sahih, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad (1 / 215, 347) with an authentic chain. This, although it has no text regarding the place, implies that picking up was at Jamrat Al-Aqaba according to the second narration and likewise the first, and most narrators are upon it. It seems Ibn Qudamah noticed this meaning so he said in "Al-Mughni" (3 / 425) "And that was at Mina". So what many pilgrims do of picking up pebbles at Muzdalifah and upon their arrival there is contrary to the Sunnah, along with the burden in it of carrying pebbles for every day. Know that there is no prevention from throwing Jamarat with pebbles that have been thrown with, as no evidence has come for prohibition. Al-Shafi'i and Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on them, said this, contrary to Ibn Taymiyyah. Then in the hadith of Al-Fadl bin Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, is that throwing with pebbles bigger than pebbles of Khadhf is extremism in religion, and it is bigger than a chickpea and smaller than a hazelnut. So what can be said about what some ignorant people do of throwing Jamarat with shoes/sandals? May Allah reform the condition of Muslims and acquaint them with the Sunnah of their Noble Prophet and grant them success to act upon it if they want true happiness in this world and the Hereafter 
[78].

85 - [So: D Hayq] he threw from the bottom of the valley [while he was on his mount [while he was: N] saying: Take your rituals (84), for I do not know, perhaps I will not perform Hajj after this Hajj of mine: M D N Hayq Ham Sa'] (85)

86 - [He said: And he threw after the Day of Nahr [in the rest of the Days of Tashreeq: Ham] (86) when the sun passed its meridian: M D N T Mi Maj Taha Ja Ha Hayq Ham]

87 - [And Suraqah met him while he was throwing Jamrat Al-Aqaba and said: O Messenger of Allah, is this for us specifically? He said: No, rather forever: Kh M Hayq Ham] (87) Slaughtering and Shaving

88 - Then he went to the place of slaughter and slaughtered sixty-three [camels (Budnah): Maj] with his own hand
foot_note:
1. (84) This Lam is Lam al-Amr (imperative Lam), meaning take your rituals as occurred in a narration other than Muslim. Its estimation is: These matters I performed in my Hajj of words, actions, and forms are the matters of Hajj and its description, and they are your rituals. So take them from me, accept them, memorize them, act upon them, and teach them to people. This hadith is a great principle in the rituals of Hajj, and it is like his saying, peace be upon him, in prayer: "Pray as you have seen me praying." Nawawi 
85. In it is an indication of bidding them farewell and announcing to them the nearness of his death, peace be upon him, and urging them to care about taking from him and seizing the opportunity to accompany him and learn matters of religion. For this reason, it was called the Farewell Hajj. From him 
[79].

89 - Then he gave to Ali so he slaughtered what remained [he says: what was left: D Ja Hayq] and he made him a partner in his sacrificial animal

90 - Then he ordered a piece (Bad'ah) (88) from every camel, so it was put in a pot and cooked, so they ate from its meat and drank from its broth

91 - (And in a narration he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, slaughtered a cow on behalf of his wives: M)

92 - (And in another he said: So we slaughtered the camel (and in another: the camel was slaughtered: Ham) for seven and the cow for seven: M Nakh Ham) (And in a fifth narration from him he said: So we shared in the camel seven [people]. A man said to him: What about the cow, can it be shared? He said: It is only from the Budn (camels/cows for sacrifice): Nakh)
foot_note:
1. (86) They are the three days following the Day of Nahr. The opinion of the majority of scholars is that throwing is not permissible in these three days except after Zawal (sun passing meridian) due to this hadith. Al-Nawawi said: "And know that throwing the Jamarat of the Days of Tashreeq requires order, which is starting with the First Jamrah next to Masjid Al-Khaif, then the Middle one, then Jamrat Al-Aqaba. Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, detailed that where she said: "So those who had raised their voice with Umrah circumambulated the House and between Safa and Marwa, then they became lawful, then they circumambulated another Tawaf after they returned from Mina. As for those who combined Hajj and Umrah, they only circumambulated one Tawaf". Extracted by the Two Sheikhs. Ibn Al-Qayyim said in "Zad Al-Ma'ad": Either it is said Aisha affirmed and Jabir denied and the affirming is prioritized over the denying, or it is said: Jabir's intent is whoever combined with the Prophet, peace be upon him, and drove the sacrificial animal like Abu Bakr, Umar, Talha, Ali and the wealthy, for they only performed Sa'y once and the intent is not the generality of Companions, or Aisha's hadith is defected that her saying: So he circumambulated etc... in the hadith is interpolated (Mudraj) from the saying of Hisham. These are three paths for people regarding her hadith. And Allah knows best. So in Zad Al-Ma'ad. I say: The last path of them is weak because declaring a trustworthy person mistaken without proof is not permissible, especially if he is like Hisham. Then I rectified and said: There is no Hisham in the path of the hadith because it is from the narration of Malik from Ibn Shihab from Urwa bin Al-Zubair from her. This is a chain extremely authentic, so who is the error and interpolation from? Then I found Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in "Manasik Al-Hajj" (p. 385 Vol. 2 of Majmu'at Al-Rasa'il Al-Kubra): It has been narrated in the hadith of Aisha that they circumambulated twice, but this addition was said to be from the saying of Al-Zuhri not from the saying of Aisha. Al-Zuhri is a mountain in memorization, so how is he declared mistaken by mere "it was said"? I add now in this edition and say: It is strange that Ibn Taymiyyah relies on that and rejects Aisha's hadith with it, saying: Some of them used it - meaning the addition - as evidence that two Tawafs of the House are recommended, and this is weak. The more apparent is what is in Jabir's hadith, supported by his saying: Umrah has entered into Hajj until the Day of Judgment. I say: Aisha's hadith is authentic without doubt, and what it was defected with is not worth mentioning as known. What confirms that are two things: First: That it has another path from her in "Al-Muwatta" (Number: 223 Vol. 1: 410) from Abdul-Rahman Ibn Al-Qasim from his father with it, and this is an authentic chain like a mountain in establishment. The other is that it has an explicit authentic witness from the hadith of Ibn Abbas that he was asked about Mut'ah of Hajj so he said: The Muhajirin and Ansar and the wives of the Prophet, peace be upon him, raised their voices in the Farewell Hajj. When we arrived in Mecca the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: Make your Ihlal with Hajj an Umrah except whoever garlanded the sacrificial animal". We circumambulated the House and Safa and Marwa and approached women and wore clothes. And he said: "Whoever garlanded the sacrificial animal, it is not lawful for him until the sacrificial animal reaches its place. Then he commanded us on the evening of Tarwiyah to raise our voices with Hajj. When we finished the rituals we came and circumambulated the House and Safa and Marwa, so our Hajj was complete and upon us was the sacrificial animal..." The hadith extracted by Al-Bukhari as suspended asserted, and Muslim narrated it outside his Sahih connected, and likewise Al-Isma'ili in his Mustakhraj, and from his path Al-Bayhaqi in his Sunan (5 / 23) and its chain is authentic, its men are men of Sahih. This all confirms the invalidity of the claim of interpolation in the hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, and supports that she memorized what Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, did not memorize. It indicates that Tamattu' necessitates Tawaf again between Safa and Marwa. In the hadith of Ibn Abbas is another very important benefit, which is that whoever does that, his Hajj is complete, and its implication is that whoever does not do that, his Hajj is not complete. This, if it does not indicate that it is a pillar, at least indicates obligation, so how recommendation? As for Sheikh Al-Islam's support for what he went to of non-legitimacy by his saying, peace be upon him: "Entered Umrah...", its weakness is not hidden after the command for it was established from the Prophet, peace be upon him and his family and companions 
[87].

For the Sunnah is of two types: Sunnah of action and Sunnah of abandonment. So whatever he (peace be upon him) abandoned of those acts of worship, it is Sunnah to abandon them. Do you not see, for example, that the Adhan for the two Eids and for burying the deceased, despite being a remembrance and glorification of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, was not permissible to use as a means to draw near to Allah, the Mighty and Majestic? That is only because it is a Sunnah that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) abandoned. His companions (peace be upon him) understood this meaning, so warnings against innovations abounded from them, a general warning as mentioned in its place, until Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman (may Allah be pleased with him) said: "Every act of worship that the companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) did not perform, do not perform it." And Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) said: "Follow and do not innovate, for you have been sufficed; stick to the ancient affair." So congratulations to him whom Allah has granted success in his worship to follow the Sunnah of His Prophet (peace be upon him) and has not mixed it with innovation. If so, then let him rejoice in Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, accepting his obedience and admitting him into His Paradise. May Allah make us among those who listen to speech and follow the best of it. Know that the innovations that you will encounter are of two types: Innovations for which I found someone among the people of knowledge stating their innovated nature in their books; for these, the sign is attributing them to them. This type is the majority. And the other: Innovations [100]

for which I did not find anyone stating their innovated nature, but the Sunnah or the fundamental scholarly rules judge them to be innovations. The evidence for this is its lack of attribution. The reference for these innovations is [several] matters: First: Weak Hadiths that are not permissible to use as proof nor attribute to the Prophet (peace be upon him). Working by such is not permissible according to us, as I have explained in the introduction to "Sifat Salat an-Nabi" (Description of the Prophet's Prayer), and it is the school of thought of a group of the people of knowledge like Ibn Taymiyyah and others. Second: Fabricated Hadiths or those with no basis, the matter of which was hidden from some jurists, especially the later ones among them. They did not support them with any Shariah evidence; rather, they cited them as taken-for-granted matters until they became Sunnahs to be followed. It is not hidden from one with insight into his religion that this is something that is not permissible to follow, for there is no Shariah except what Allah the Exalted legislated. It is enough for the one who deems something good - if he is a Mujtahid - that it be permissible for him alone to act upon what he deemed good, and that Allah does not hold him accountable for it. As for people taking that as a Shariah and a Sunnah, then no, and again no. How [can that be] when some of them contradict the practical Sunnah, as will be pointed out, Allah the Exalted willing [101]

Fourth: Customs and superstitions indicated by neither Shariah nor attested to by reason, even if some ignorant people act upon them and take them as a law for themselves, and do not intend [to follow] anyone who supports them, even if in some of that, among those who claim knowledge and dress in their garb. Then let it be known that these innovations are not of one level of danger; rather, they are of degrees. Some of them are Shirk and explicit Kufr (disbelief), as you will see, and some are less than that. But we must know that the smallest innovation a man brings into the religion is forbidden after its nature as an innovation becomes clear. Innovations do not contain - as some imagine - that which is only of the rank of Makruh (disliked). How [can that be] when the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) says: (Sahih) "Every innovation is misguidance, and every misguidance is in the Fire," meaning its doer. Imam Al-Shatibi (may Allah have mercy on him) has verified this most completely in his great book "Al-I'tisam". Therefore, the matter of innovation is very dangerous. Most people are still heedless of it, and only a group of the people of knowledge know that. Sufficient for you as evidence of the danger of innovation is his saying (peace be upon him): (Sahih) "Indeed, Allah has blocked repentance from every person of innovation until he leaves his innovation." I conclude this word with advice I present to the readers from a great Imam among the early scholars of the Muslims, Sheikh Al-Hasan bin Ali Al-Barbahari [101]

91 - What is widely circulated on the tongues of the common people that standing at Arafat on a Friday is equivalent to seventy-two Hajjs (Zad al-Ma'ad) (1 / 23) (158)

92 - (The definition (Ta'rif) that some people do by intentionally gathering on the evening of the Day of Arafah in mosques or a place outside the town, supplicating and remembering Allah with loud voices, sermons, and poetry, imitating the people of Arafat). (Sunan Al-Bayhaqi) (5 / 118) from Al-Hakam, Hammad, and Ibrahim, and (Al-Iqtida') (149) and (Munyat al-Musalli) by Al-Halabi (573). Innovations of Muzdalifah
foot_note:
1. (157) Sheikh al-Islam said in his "Majmu'" (2 / 380): The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not designate a specific supplication or Dhikr for Arafat. Rather, a man supplicates with whatever legal supplications he wishes, and likewise, he says Takbir, Tahlil, and remembers Allah the Exalted until the sun sets. I say: It should be added to this that it is Sunnah for him to recite Talbiyah as well; see the previous comment number (64).
158. The origin of this innovation is a fabricated hadith indicated by Ibn al-Qayyim in the aforementioned source. He said: It is false and has no basis from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). So do not be deceived by what the scholar Al-Kawthari quoted in "Al-Ajwiba Al-Fadila" (p. 37, Aleppo edition) from Sheikh Ali Al-Qari that he said: "As for some Hadith scholars mentioning that it is weak in its chain, assuming it is authentic [in meaning], it does not harm the intent. For weak hadith is considered in virtuous deeds according to all scholars of perfection. We do not know of anyone who stated only its weakness, despite the ruling of the researcher Ibn al-Qayyim of its falsehood." This reality is one of the many examples of the ominousness of what some adopt regarding acting upon weak hadith in virtuous deeds, despite their frequent disagreement in interpreting this doctrine, as you find detailed in the aforementioned Answers. A hadith might be false like this one, yet some label it as weak, then another comes and says one acts upon weak hadith in virtuous deeds without verifying its safety from severe weakness, which is one of the conditions for acting upon it. Note that absolute weakness does not negate severe weakness, nor even fabrication, because they are types of weak hadith as established in the terminology. Moreover, I wonder what is the relation of this hadith to acting upon weak hadith? For that applies where a person has a choice to do or leave something, which is not the case for standing at Arafat coinciding with Friday. Furthermore, you can find the text of the false hadith referred to in my book "Silsilat al-Ahadith al-Da'ifah wa al-Mawdu'ah" number (207) with a mention of the scholars who agreed with Ibn al-Qayyim on his ruling of the hadith's falsehood.
[126].
